etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Mona's Herald. From Manx cuishag, cushag ragweed, stalk, cognate with or formed similarly to Irish cuiseog slender stem, stalk from cos leg, stem, shaft (Early Irish cos; from the same Indo-European base as classical Latin coxa hip) + -og, diminutive suffix

notes.text: Frequently regarded as or said to be the (unofficial) national flower of the Isle of Man, sometimes in ironic allusion to supposedly poor or wasteful agricultural practices.
